body_text.text:
pDONR221 vector containing the open reading frame  (ORF) of interest.pBG1805 vector: c-terminal His6X-3C-Protein A “zz” domain or pYES-DEST52 for His6X-V5 fusion proteins.Flanking sequences for integration into Gateway pDONR221 plasmid

att B4: 5′ GGGGCAACTTTGTATAGAAAAGTTG 3′ (added to the 5′ PCR primer).
att B1: 5′ GGGGCTGCTTTTTTGTACAAACTTG 3′ (added to the 3′ PCR primer).
Sequencing primers for pBG1805 plasmid
F5: 5′ CATTTTCGGTTTGTATTACTTCTTATTC 3′.R3: 5′ GGACCTTGAAAAAGAACTTC 3′.

S. cerevisiae genomic DNA (strain BY4700, MATa ura3Δ0).
S. cerevisiae Y258: MATa, pep4, his4-58, ura3-52, leu 2-3, 112.
Pfx polymerase (Invitrogen) or Pfu Ultra polymerase (Stratagene).BsrG1 endonuclease for screening positive clones.Culture tubes.Agarose.LB plus Kanamycin, both liquid, and 2% bacto-agar.
10 g tryptone.5 g yeast extract.5 g NaCl.20 g agar (for plates).Make up to 1 L with distilled water (dH2O).Autoclave and allow to cool prior to addition of 50 μg/mL of ampicillin final concentration.
DNA ladder
E. coli: DH5αTAE
242 g Tris base.57.1 mL 100% glacial acetic acid.100 mL 0.5 M ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) (pH 8.0).Make up with dH2O up to 1 L.
LR clonase (Invitrogen).BP clonase (Invitrogen).
body_text.section: Generation of C-Terminally Tagged Yeast Strains ::: Materials

body_text.text:
YPAD (Yeast extract-peptone-adenine-dextrose)
10 g bacto yeast extract.20 g bacto peptone.50 mg adenine.20 g dextrose.20 g agar (for plates).Make up with dH2O up to 1 L.
1 M lithium acetate (LiAc).50% polyethylene glycol (PEG).10 mg/mL ssDNA.DNA.dH2O.Water bath or heat block.96-well box.96-well polymerase chain reaction (PCR) plate.Synthetic complete minus uracil media (Sc-ura)
1.5 g yeast nitrogen base.5 g (NH4)2SO4.
2 g Sc-ura drop out mix (commercially available).20 g raffinose (or dextrose for starter culture media and SD-ura plates).20 g agar (for plates).

3× YEP–GAL (yeast extract–peptone–galactose)
30 g yeast extract.60 g peptone.Make up to 700 mL with dH2O.Add 300 mL of sterile filtered 20% galactose to media after autoclaving.
0.5 mm zirconia beads or acid-washed glass beads.Lysis buffer 150
50 mM Tris–HCL at pH 7.5.150 mM NaCl.1 mM ethyleneglycoltetraacetic acid (EGTA).10% glycerol.0.1% Triton X-100.0.5 mM dithiothreitol (DTT).1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (PMSF).1× complete protease inhibitor tablet (Roche).
Paint shaker (5G-HD, Harbil) or similar mechanism to break cells.SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) gels.Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) or nitrocellulose membranes.Multichannel pipette.Semi-dry transfer apparatus.HRP-IgG.HA antibody (16B12, Covance).Imaging Film (Kodak BioMax MR Film).

Wash buffer (150)
50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5).150 mM NaCl.10% glycerol.0.1% and Triton X-100.
Elution buffer
50 mM Tris (pH 7.5).150 mM NaCl.25% glycerol.0.1% Triton X-100.
96-well box.PVDF 96-well filter plate (1.2-μm pore size).IgG-Fast Flow 6 Sepharose.3C protease.384-well microplate (to array proteins).Adhesive foil lids for sealing microplates.
body_text.section: Preparation of Proteins for Protein Microarray ::: Materials

body_text.text: Arrays suitable for assay being performed.Bio-Rad ChipWriter Pro or comparable printer.

Phosphate buffered saline (PBS) lysis solution
PBS (0.01 M phosphate buffer, 0.0027 M potassium chloride, 0.137 M sodium chloride; pH 7.4).0.1% Triton X-100.0.5 mM DTT.2 mM MgCl2..500 mM NaCl.50 mM imidazole (pH 7.4).1 mM PMSF.Complete protease inhibitor cocktail – EDTA-free (Roche).Phosphatase inhibitor Cocktail 1 (Sigma).

2.Ni2+, or Co2+ affinity resin.3.G25 columns.4.Microcentrifuge.5.Wash buffer
PBS (0.01 M phosphate buffer, 0.0027 M potassium chloride, 0.137 M sodium chloride; pH 7.4).0.1% Triton X-100.500 mM NaCl.0.5 mM DTT.50 mM imidazole (pH 7.4).2 mM MgCl2.

6.Elution buffer
PBS (0.01 M phosphate buffer, 0.0027 M potassium chloride, 0.137 M sodium chloride; pH = 7.4).0.1% Triton X-100.500 mM NaCl.0.5 mM DTT.500 mM imidazole (pH 7.4).2 mM MgCl2..20% glycerol (if freezing at −80°).

Blocking buffer
PBS (0.01 M phosphate buffer, 0.0027 M potassium chloride, 0.137 M sodium chloride; pH 7.4).1% bovine serum albumin (BSA).0.1% Tween-20.
Probe buffer
PBS (0.01 M phosphate buffer, 0.0027 M potassium chloride, 0.137 M sodium chloride; pH 7.4).2 mM MgCl2..0.5 mM DTT.0.05% Triton X-100.50 mM NaCl.500 µM ATP (for kinases).1% BSA.

Lysis Buffer
100 mM Tris–HCl pH 7.4.100 mM NaCl, 1 mM EGTA.0.1% 2-mercaptoethanol.0.1% Triton X-100, protease cocktail (Roche).1 mM EDTA.50 mM NaF.10 mM sodium glycerophosphate.1 mM Na3VO4.

Kinase Buffer
100 mM Tris–HCl pH 8.0.100 mM NaCl.10 mM MgCl2..20 mM glutathione.20% glycerol.
Superblock (Pierce)[33P]ATP

Design forward primers containing the att B4 sequence and reverse primers with the att B1 sequence (see
subheading
2.1 and Note
4) for the gene of interest.Amplify the gene of interest by PCR using the previously mentioned genomic DNA and polymerase (see
subheading
2.1).Perform BP clonase reaction (5 µL) using 30–300 ng of PCR product added to 150 ng of pDONR221 plasmid and following manufacturer’s instructions.Incubate the reaction overnight at 25°C.Combine half of the of the BP reaction (3 µL) with 150 ng of pBG1805 DNA or pYES-DEST52 (for V5 fusion) backbone, 0.6 µL of LR clonase, and 0.6 µL of LR clonase 10× buffer.Incubate the reaction overnight at 25°C and use half of the reaction to transform DH5α cells.Plate the cells on LB/ampicillin (see
Subheading
2.1, item 11) plates overnight at 37°C.Miniprep overnight cultures of several colonies of each transformant grown in LB/ampicillin liquid media.Digest with 5 μL of DNA with BsrG1 overnight at 37°C to confirm the presence of insert and sequence clones that contain the insert using sequencing primers (see
Subheading
2.1, item 4).
body_text.section: Constructing a Large Number of Clones for Protein Arrays ::: High-Throughput Preparation of Clones ::: Methods

body_text.text:
Inoculate 20 mL YPAD (see
subheading
2.2, item 1) with a starter culture of a fresh Y258 colony from YPAD agarose plate.Inoculate 50 mL of YPAD/10 transformations with enough starter culture to attain an OD600 of 0.1.Grow for several doubling times to an OD600 of ∼0.6–0.8.Transfer the cells to a 50-mL conical tube and spin in a tabletop centrifuge at 3,000 rpm/5 min/4°C.Bring up to a volume of 50 mL with water to wash, and repeat centrifugation.Decant water and add 0.5 mL 100 mM LiAc and transfer to a 1.5-mL snap-cap tube.Spin at 13,000 rpm in a microfuge for 30 s and remove the solution with a pipette.Add enough 100 mM LiAc to bring the volume up to 0.5 mL, and vortex to suspend the cells.Aliquot 50 μL of the suspension into separate snap-cap tubes and centrifuge.Remove liquid as before and prepare pellet for transformation.Add 240 µL of 50% PEG solution, 36 μL of 1 M LiAC, 10 μL of 10 mg/mL ssDNA, 2 μL of miniprepped DNA fusion construct, and 72 μL of dH20.Vortex the mixture and incubate at 30°C for 30 min.Next, move the tubes to a water bath set to 42°C for 30 min.Finally, spin the tubes at 10,000 ´ g for 15 s, and aspirate the solution with a pipette.Add 500 mL of dH2O to each tube and vortex briefly.Pipette 50–100 μL of suspension onto Sc-ura/2% dextrose agar Petri dishes (see
subheading
2.2, item 10).Allow 48 h to recover and screen the transformants by immunoblot.
body_text.section: Transforming Yeast with C-Terminal Tagged ORF ::: High-Throughput Preparation of Clones ::: Methods

body_text.text:
Inoculate 96-well starter cultures in 0.8 mL of SD-ura/2% dextrose.On day 2, wash the cells with Sc-ura/2% raffinose (see
subheading
2.2, item 10), and inoculate 5 μL of starter culture into a new 96-well box (2 mL/well) containing 0.8 mL of Sc-ura/2% raffinose with a 3.5-mm glass ball (PGC scientific) in each well for mixing and aeration.Mix cells for 15 h at 30°C on a platform shaker and then induce by addition of 0.4 mL of 3× YEP-GAL (see
subheading
2.3, item 1) for 6 h, and follow by centrifugation and washing with ice cold water and storage at −80°C.Obtain the lysates by adding 200 μL of lysis buffer 150 (see
subheading
2.3, item 2) and shaking for 6 min in a paint shaker (5G-HD, Harbil) at 4°C with 250 μL of acid-washed glass beads (0.5 mm, Sigma), followed by centrifugation at 1,000 ´ g for 5 min.Combine the crude lysates with 5× SDS loading buffer in a 96-well PCR plate, heat for 5 min at 95°C, and centrifuge again at 2,500 rpm 5 min.Remove 12 μL from each well with a multichannel pipette and load onto SDS-PAGE gels.Western transfer to either PVDF or nitrocellulose membranes using standard wet or dry transfer techniques.Block the membrane with TBS/0.1% Tween–1% milk powder for 1 h.Probe with anti-HA antibodies (16B12, 1:1,000, Covance) overnight in TBS/0.1% Tween–1% milk powder.On day 2, wash the membrane three times with TBS/0.1% Tween, 10 min each wash.Probe for 1 h at room temperature with HRP-conjugated sheep anti-mouse IgG antibody (Amersham).Wash the membrane three times with TBS/0.1% Tween, 10 min each wash, and develop with Supersignal west chemiluminescent substrate (Pierce).
body_text.section: High-Throughput Immunoblot Analysis ::: High-Throughput Assaying and Preparation of Protein Methods for Assay Protein Expression and High-Throughput Preparation of Proteins ::: High-Throughput Preparation of Clones ::: Methods

body_text.text:
Inoculate 96-well starter cultures in 0.8 mL of Sc-ura medium.On day 2, wash the cells with Sc-ura/2% raffinose, and inoculate 5 μL of starter culture into a new 96-well box (2 mL/well) containing 0.8 mL of Sc-ura/2% raffinose with a 3.5-mm glass ball (PGC scientific) in each well for mixing and aeration.Mix cells for 15 h at 30°C on a platform shaker and then induce by addition of 0.4 mL of 3× YEP-GAL (see
Subheading 
2.3, item 1) for 6 h followed by centrifugation, washing with ice cold water, and storage at −80°C.Obtain the lysates by adding 200 μL of lysis buffer 150 (see
Subheading
2.3, item 2) and shaking for 6 min in a paint shaker (5G-HD, Harbil) at 4°C with 250 μL of acid-washed glass beads (0.5 mm, Sigma), followed by centrifugation at 2,500 rpm for 5 min.Transfer the cleared lysate to a new 96-well box along with IgG Sepharose resin (6 Fast Flow; GE Biosciences) and incubate at 4°C for several hours with agitation.Afterwards, wash the beads  four times with wash buffer 150 (see
Subheading
2.4, item 1)Transfer the beads to a PVDF filter plate (1.2 µm pore size) and spin-through the excess wash. Suspend the resin is in 40 µL of elution buffer containing1 µL of 3C protease for 18 h at 4°C with agitation.The next day, add preconditioned glutathione beads  to the reaction to remove the 3C protease and spin the eluted protein through the PVDF membrane into a clean 96-well freezer plate.Array the proteins into 5 μL aliquots on multiple 384-well printing plates and cover with an adhesive aluminum seal for storage at −80°C until printing.Include a control plate with assay-specific controls (see
Note
2).
body_text.section: Purifying Proteins for Arrays ::: High-Throughput Assaying and Preparation of Protein Methods for Assay Protein Expression and High-Throughput Preparation of Proteins ::: High-Throughput Preparation of Clones ::: Methods

body_text.text:
Once proteins are prepared they must be printed onto surfaces, typically microscope slides. A variety of different surfaces exist for preparing protein microarrays. They include nitrocellulose and aldehyde surface chemistries for chemical attachment through lysines and affinity attachment methods such as nickel-chelated slides for attaching His tagged proteins and glutathione for affinity attachment (
15, 3, 16
). The different surfaces have advantages and disadvantages; nitrocellulose allows the attachment of large amounts of protein, and it along with chemical attachment methods results in random orientation of proteins away from the surface. It is likely that the activity of the attached molecule is lost for many molecules attached by these methods. Moreover, binding of probes to regions near the surface is likely to be sterically inhibited. Affinity attachment methods are more likely to retain activity and orient proteins away from the surface, although random presentation of protein surfaces from the slide is not attained. Different surfaces yield different backgrounds and it is prudent to test several surfaces whenever a new assay is employed.
Configure the contact arrayer and align the microscope slides (FAST, Path, or other types of slides see
Note
1) to allow the maximum number of slides to be printed per run. This will vary depending on the arrayer used, but for the Bio-Rad ChipWriter Pro it is approximately 90 arrays/run.Maintain a constant humidity of ∼40% in the printing chamber, and a constant temperature of 4°C (this is achieved by placing the printer in a temperature-controlled cold room).Remove two plates at a time from the −80°C storage, and allow them to thaw on ice for 5–10 min followed by centrifugation at 1,000 × g at 4°C for 2 min.Remove the foil seal from the top of the plate and place the plate into the chamber in the proper orientation for printing (see manufacturer’s instructions).After the print run, cover the plate with a new aluminum seal and return to the −80°C freezer.Repeat for each plate.After printing, store the arrays in a −20°C non-deicing freezer, which can remain stable for up to 1 year.
body_text.section: Printing Protein Microarrays ::: High-Throughput Preparation of Clones ::: Methods

body_text.text: Protein microarrays can be screened for a wide variety of activities. A common activity is interaction with other proteins. One of the best ways to perform this is to produce the protein of interest with an epitope tag (we prefer to use the V5 epitope for yeast) and probe a yeast proteome chip as follows:
body_text.section: Probing for Protein–Protein Interactions with Protein Microarrays ::: High-Throughput Preparation of Clones ::: Methods

body_text.text:
Dilute the protein probe over a concentration range of 5–500 µg/mL, which must be optimized for each protein–protein interaction assay (see
Fig. 1). The purified V5-fusion protein is diluted into the probe buffer (see
Subheading
2.7, item 2).

Remove the arrays from the freezer (−20°C) and bring to 4°C in the refrigerator, just prior to use, for about 15–20 min. Block the arrays in blocking buffer (see
Subheading
2.7, item 1) for 1 h by shaking at 50 rpm on a stage at 4°C.After blocking, transfer the arrays to a humidity chamber, and add 90 µL of diluted probe directly to the array surface. Overlay the arrays with a raised lifter slip and incubate static (no shaking) in the humidor for 1.5 h.Wash the arrays 3 times for 1 min each in probe buffer in three 50-mL conical tubes (see
Note
4).To detect interactions, dilute the V5-AlexaFluor 647 antibody to 260 ng/mL in probe buffer and mix thoroughly by shaking.After washing the arrays several times as indicated, add antibody solution directly to array and overlay with a raised lifter slip as before. Incubate the arrays for 30 min/static/4°C.Finally, wash the arrays for 1 min (3×) in probe buffer, and spin in a 50-mL conical tube at 800g in a tabletop centrifuge for 5 min at room temperature. Air-dry the arrays in a slide holder in the dark for 30 min prior to scanning the array at 647 nm.
body_text.section: Probing the Arrays ::: Purifying the V5-Fusion Protein Probe ::: High-Throughput Preparation of Clones ::: Methods

body_text.text:
Another useful application of protein microarrays is to identify targets of protein modification enzymes. Recently, a large study has been performed to identify the targets of 87 distinct protein kinases of yeast (
12
). A protocol for screening for targets of protein kinases is as follows:
Grow cells in 50–500-mL cultures, harvest, and lyse, with glass beads in the lysis buffer (see
Subheading
2.7, item 1) as in “Purifying Proteins for Arrays.”Kinases-GST fusions are bound to glutathione beads and eluted into the kinase buffer (see
Subheading
2.7, item 2).Block the proteome arrays in a Superblock (Pierce) with 0.1% Triton X-100 for 1 h at 4°C and probe in duplicate for every kinase.Optimize conditions: Dilute the kinase into kinase buffer plus 0.5 mg/mL BSA, 0.1% Triton X-100, and 2 L of [33P]ATP (33.3 nM final concentration).Overlay each kinase in buffer on two arrays, cover with a coverslip, and place in a humidified chamber at 30°C for 1 h.Wash the slides twice with 10 mM Tris–HCl pH 7.4, 0.5% SDS and once with double-distilled water before being spun dry and exposed to X-ray film (Kodak).For each experiment, incubate two additional arrays with kinase buffer in the absence of kinase, which will serve as autophosphorylation reference slides.
body_text.section: Identifying Protein Kinase Substrate with Protein Arrays ::: High-Throughput Preparation of Clones ::: Methods

body_text.text: Care needs to be taken when printing samples with high glycerol content on surfaces other than nitrocellulose (nickel, ultrgap, etc.) in high humidity >40% because the spot diameter will differ and this could result in samples bleeding together.Probe-specific control spots must be added to each array. These include known concentrations of 3C protease (if used) as well as Alexa Fluor V5 antibody and V5-fusion constructs. These will be used to ascertain optimal probing conditions and antibody titer for protein probing experiments.Primers for sequencing of V5-fusions in pYES-DEST52 can be obtained from Invitrogen’s Website. ORFs can be shuttles from any of the destination (DEST) vectors using the pDONR221 as an intermediary.When probing for protein–protein interactions, it is advisable to wash the arrays using three separate 50-mL conical tubes per slide. Allow the slides to remain submerged in the first chamber until the lifter slip falls off (do not pull it off with force). Afterward, proceed with 1 min washes, gently removing slides with forceps from each bath by gripping the nonmembraneous portion of the slide.
